Question:
# Titus Study Questions

The Apostle Paul left Titus in Crete and gave him the responsibility to teach the new believers there, and to appoint elders in the local churches. Titus was a godly man, but he was not have as much experience as Paul did in guiding the formation of the new churches. In this letter, therefore, Paul counsels Titus concerning:

* How Titus should fulfil his task
* The kind of men he should appoint as elders
* The type of threats that existed that could damage the new believers
* How believers should act in their daily lifes
* What is the hope that the believers look forward to
* How believers should interact with secular authorities and those who do not believe in Jesus
* The precise message that we should believe and teach
* How to deal with division within the church

You can discover Paul’s teaching concerning each of these things by carefully reading each chapter of the letter. Ask yourself questions about what you read, and pray to God that he will open your eyes to see clearly.
How did Paul describe himself to Titus?
Why do you think Paul described himself as a **servant** before he described himself as an **apostle**?
In what ways was Paul **a servant of God**?
Would you prefer to be a servant or an apostle? Why?
The word Paul used for **servant** is also the word for “slave.” Does that change your understanding of how Paul described himself? How?
What do people in your culture think about servants or slaves?

Quote: δοῦλος Θεοῦ, ἀπόστολος δὲ Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
Question: In this verse, for what two purposes did Paul say he was **a servant of God and an an apostle of Jesus Christ**?
What **faith** do you think Paul wanted the chosen people of God to have?
Why did Paul call the believers **the chosen people of God**?
From among whom did God choose the believers? Why did he choose them?
How might it change your life if you truly believed that God chose you?
Why do you think it was so important for Paul that God’s chosen people had **the knowledge of the truth**?
What do you think is **the truth** that believers must know?
What do you think Paul was referring to when he spoke of **godliness**?
Why is it important that **the knowledge** of the believers **agrees with godliness**?
What things can you think of that are true, but that are not godly?
Paul speaks of both **truth** and **godliness** together. What problems happen when someone or some group has one of these without the other?
Paul referred to the **certain hope of everlasting life**. Why is this hope **certain** for believers?
What do we learn about God’s character in this verse?
When did God make the promise everlasting life to believers?
Why was it **the right time** when God revealed his word?
How did God reveal his word?
What does it mean to **entrust** something to another person?
What effect do you think it had on Paul to be entrusted to proclaim God’s word?
What title does Paul use for God in this verse, and why would it be important?
What does Paul mean when he calls Titus **a true son in our common faith**?
Paul greeted Titus with **Grace and peace from God**. How does this compare to the way people in your culture greet one another?

Quote: χάρις καὶ εἰρήνη ἀπὸ Θεοῦ Πατρὸς καὶ Χριστοῦ Ἰησοῦ τοῦ Σωτῆρος ἡμῶν
Question: Why would Paul expect grace and peace to come from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Savior?
What title does Paul use for Jesus in this verse? How does that affect your understanding of the title for God in verse 3?

Quote: ἵνα τὰ λείποντα ἐπιδιορθώσῃ, καὶ καταστήσῃς κατὰ πόλιν πρεσβυτέρους
Question: Why did Paul leave Titus in Crete?
What does it mean to set things in order?
What do you think might have been **not yet complete** in Crete?
Where was Titus to ordain elders?
How would you describe a person who is **blameless**?
What does Paul mean when he says an elder must be **the husband of one wife**? Who would qualify?
What does it mean for children to be **faithful**?
Why might it be important that the children of an elder not be **accused of reckless behavior or rebellion**? How might those things hinder his ministry?
If you have a family, would it meet these conditions for you to be an elder? Why or why not?
Why is it important that Paul says for a second time (see verse 6) that an overseer must be **blameless**?
Paul here refers to an elder as an **overseer**? Is there any difference in the meaning of these words?
Paul describes an elder as **the household manager of God**. How does that influence your understanding of the role of an elder?

Quote: μὴ αὐθάδη, μὴ ὀργίλον, μὴ πάροινον, μὴ πλήκτην, μὴ αἰσχροκερδῆ
Question: Paul says an elder should not be **arrogant**, **easily angered**, **addicted to wine**, **a brawler**, or **a greedy man**. How might each of those bad character traits hinder a man from being a good elder in the church?
Do you have any of these weaknesses that Paul listed? If so what do you plan do about that?
Would you be willing to receive counsel of teaching from a man with the characteristics listed in this verse? Why?
Why would it be important for an elder to be **hospitable**?
Do these characteristics of an elder also describe you? Why or why not? How could you do better?
What does it mean to **hold tightly** to a message?
What kind of message would be **trustworthy**?

Quote: τοῦ κατὰ τὴν διδαχὴν πιστοῦ λόγου
Question: Paul said **the trustworthy message** must be in accordance with **the teaching**. What **teaching** do you think Paul was referring to?
According to Paul in this verse, what two things will an elder be qualified to do if he **holds tightly to the trustworthy message**?
Are you **holding tightly to the trustworthy message**? In what way? How can you improve?
The word **sound** can also be translated as “healthy.” How might teaching be “healthy?”
Why would it be important for an elder to **rebuke those who oppose him**? (See verses 10-11)

Quote: παρακαλεῖν ἐν τῇ διδασκαλίᾳ τῇ ὑγιαινούσῃ, καὶ τοὺς ἀντιλέγοντας ἐλέγχειν
Question: Do you understand the message of the gospel well enough to teach and rebuke others? If not, what might you do to improve?
How does the word **For** connect this verse to the previous one?
What is an **empty talker**?
Who was Paul referring to when he spoke of **those of the circumcision**?
Do you listen to anyone who is like the people Paul described in this verse? If so, what should you do about that?
What did Paul say the elders must do to these false teachers who opposed them?
Why did Paul speak so forcefully about stopping these men who opposed the elders of the church?
In what way do you think these false teachers were **upsetting whole households**?
Why are **households** important for the growth and spiritual life of the church?
What did Paul say was the reason these false teachers were teaching their false doctrine?

Quote: τις ἐξ αὐτῶν, ἴδιος αὐτῶν προφήτης
Question: Why is it significant that the person quotes here was one of the Cretans?

Quote: Κρῆτες ἀεὶ ψεῦσται, κακὰ θηρία, γαστέρες ἀργαί
Question: Why would one of the Cretans speak so harshly about his own people?
What do you think this man meant when he said they were **lazy bellies**?

If a **prophet** from your own people group described a character weakness or sin that is common among your people, what would it be? How might elders prevent believers from continuing to act that way?
What did Paul say about the words of this Cretan prophet?

Quote: δι’ ἣν αἰτίαν ἔλεγχε αὐτοὺς ἀποτόμως
Question: When Paul tells Titus and the elders, "**For this reason, rebuke them severely**", how does that relate to verse 9?

Quote: ἔλεγχε αὐτοὺς ἀποτόμως, ἵνα ὑγιαίνωσιν ἐν τῇ πίστει
Question: Why were the Titus and the elders supposed to **rebuke** the Cretan false teachers **severely**?
What result did Paul want to happen after Titus and the elders rebuked the false teachers?
The word **sound** can also be translated as “healthy.” How might they be “healthy” **in the faith**?
Would you describe yourself as **sound in the faith**? Why or why not?
What does Paul in this verse say is one way people can be sound in the faith?
What is Paul referring to when he says **the truth**?
How should this verse affect the way we interact with false teachers or people who teach things that are not according to the gospel?

Quote: πάντα καθαρὰ τοῖς καθαροῖς; τοῖς δὲ μεμιαμμένοις καὶ ἀπίστοις, οὐδὲν καθαρόν
Question: Which is true: pure things make people pure, or pure people make things pure? What is the difference?

Quote: πάντα καθαρὰ τοῖς καθαροῖς; τοῖς δὲ μεμιαμμένοις καὶ ἀπίστοις, οὐδὲν καθαρόν
Question: Which is true: corrupt things make people corrupt, or corrupt people make things corrupt? What is the difference?
Paul says these people are both **corrupt** and **unbelieving**. How might those two traits be connected?
What is Paul referring to when he says **their minds** have been corrupted?
In what way can a person’s conscience be corrupted?
What do these false teachers say about God?
How do people know that these people do not really know God?
Why do you think Paul speaks so harshly about these false teachers?
Are these people able to do **good work**? Why or why not?
Do you know God? How would other people know if you do?
Are you fit for any good work? If not, how would you become fit?
Who is Paul contrasting Titus against when he says **But you**?
How did the rebellious people speak what did not **fit with sound teaching**?
The word **sound** used here normally refers to good health. What kind of **teaching** would you say is “healthy”?
Who would be an **Older man** in your culture?
Are the qualities of an older man that Paul lists here attractive in your culture? Why or why not?
What would be the opposite of the qualities Paul lists here? Why would those not be good older men to do?
The phrase **sound in faith** here uses the same word **sound** as verse 1 does for "teaching." How do you think faith can be “healthy”?
Who would be an **Older woman** in your culture?
Paul says older women are to be **reverent in behavior**. Is this quality of an older woman attractive in your culture? Why or why not?
Paul here says older women are not to be **slanders** or **slaves to much wine**. Do some older women in your culture have those problems?
Older women are to be **teachers of what is good**. What does this mean, and how is it different that the things Paul says not to do?
How does "they may train** in this verse connect back to the older women being **teachers of what is good** in verse 3?
Who are **younger women** in your culture?
Who are the younger women to **love**?
Why is **love** so important for the younger women to do?
Must younger women already have husbands and children before the older women can train them? Why or why not?
Why do you think Paul focuses his commands to younger women on how they love their families (husbands and children)?
The phrase **so that** expresses the result of younger women following Paul’s commands. What is that result, and why would following these commands make it possible?

Quote: μὴ ὁ λόγος τοῦ Θεοῦ βλασφημῆται
Question: Why might people insult the word of God is young believing women did not treat their families well?
Who would be the **younger men** in your culture?
Instead of a list of commands, Paul only tells Titus to exhort the younger men to be **sensible**. How might that single trait cause them to live well?
Do you think younger men struggle with being **sensible**? Why or why not?
To whom is Paul directly speaking in verses 7-8?
Why is it important that Titus be **an example of good works**? How might that affect the purpose for which Paul sent Titus to Crete?
How might a person be corrupted in his teaching? Why is it so important not to do that?
How can a person teach **with dignity**? Why is that important?
In the phrase **sound message** Paul uses the same word **sound** that he uses in verses 1-2 for **teaching** and **faith**. How might a message be “healthy”?
What kind of opponents might want to criticize the message of the gospel today? Why would they do that?

Quote: μηδὲν ἔχων λέγειν περὶ ἡμῶν φαῦλον
Question: Why would an opponent of the gospel have nothing bad to say about believers if they did what Paul commanded in verses 1-7?
Why does Paul include himself by saying **us**? Why would people say bad things about Paul if the Cretan church did not obey what Titus told them to do?
About whom is Paul speaking in verses 9-10?
The Greek language has a single word for **slave** that also means “servant”. Does it make any difference if you apply Paul’s commands to both slaves and hired servants?
Why do you think Paul commands believing **slaves to be **subject to their own masters** instead of trying to free themselves?
How might a slave **be pleasing** to his master?
What does it mean to **demonstrate all good faith** and how is that different from arguing and stealing?
The phrase **so that** introduces the reason slaves should submit to their masters. What is that reason?

Quote: τὴν διδασκαλίαν τὴν τοῦ Σωτῆρος ἡμῶν, Θεοῦ, κοσμῶσιν
Question: How do believing slaves ** bring credit to the teaching that is about God our Savior** when they submit to their masters?
Compare **God our Savior** to the similar title in verse 13. To whom does this title refer?
The word **For** which begins this verse introduces the reason why slaves should submit to their masters. What is that reason?
For what purpose did **the grace of God** appear?
Who is the grace of God able to save?

The grace of God makes possible the salvation of all people. Does that mean that all people are saved? In other words, are the rebellious people and deceivers and corrupt people in chapter 1 also saved?

Quote: ἀρνησάμενοι τὴν ἀσέβειαν καὶ τὰς κοσμικὰς ἐπιθυμίας
Question: What does the grace of God train us to reject?
What are the **worldly passions** that we are to reject?

Quote: σωφρόνως καὶ δικαίως, καὶ εὐσεβῶς, ζήσωμεν
Question: How does the grace of God train us to live?
What is **the present age** and why should we live in a sensible, righteous, and godly way during it?
What is it that believers are looking forward to as they live in this present age?

Quote: τὴν μακαρίαν ἐλπίδα, καὶ ἐπιφάνειαν τῆς δόξης τοῦ μεγάλου Θεοῦ καὶ Σωτῆρος ἡμῶν, Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
Question: Paul speaks of **the blessed hope** and the **appearing of the glory of our great God and Savior Jesus Christ** as two names for the same event. What do these titles tell you about that event?
What does Paul mean when he says our hope is **blessed**?
Why does Paul not simply refer to the appearance of Christ, but instead to the appearing **of the glory** of Christ?

Quote: τοῦ μεγάλου Θεοῦ καὶ Σωτῆρος ἡμῶν, Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ
Question: It is not clear in the text if **our great God and Savior Jesus Christ** refers to both God and Father and Jesus, or if it is one title referring to Jesus. How do you understand this verse? What difference does it make?
Considering your answer to the last question in verse 13, to whom does **He** refer in this verse?
What does Paul mean when he says that Christ **gave himself**?
The phrase **in order to** introduces the reason Jesus gave himself. What is that reason?
The word **redeem** is used for slaves who are bought back from the slave market. How can **lawlessness** cause people to be like slaves?
What specifically does Jesus want believers to be zealous to do?
To whom is Paul again speaking directly in verse 15?

Quote: λάλει, καὶ παρακάλει, καὶ ἔλεγχε, μετὰ πάσης ἐπιταγῆς
Question: What does it mean to **speak**, **exhort**, and **rebuke with all authority**?
In 1:9 Paul tells Titus to rebuke those who oppose him. Would there ever be a reason to also rebuke believers?
Paul tells Titus not to let people disregard him. Why was that necessary? Who might do that, and why?
To whom is Paul again speaking directly in verse 1?
Who are the **them** who must submit to rulers and authorities?
Who are the **rulers and authorities** to whom they should submit?
Is there any difference between **submit** and **obey**? Why did Paul use both terms?

Quote: πρὸς πᾶν ἔργον ἀγαθὸν ἑτοίμους εἶναι
Question: How might obeying authorities prepare us to do good works?
To whom are believers to show humility?
by saying **we also**, Paul includes himself along with Titus and the believers in Crete. When did they live as this verse describes? When did you live this way?

Quote: πλανώμενοι, δουλεύοντες ἐπιθυμίαις καὶ ἡδοναῖς ποικίλαις
Question: Paul uses the image of a person being led astray and made a slave, What does that teach you about the way passion and pleasure can affect a person?
What are some of the passions and pleasures that enslave people?

Quote: ἡ χρηστότης καὶ ἡ φιλανθρωπία ἐπεφάνη τοῦ Σωτῆρος ἡμῶν, Θεοῦ
Question: How did God respond to the evil way in which we formerly lived?
What title does Paul again use for God in this verse?

Quote: οὐκ ἐξ ἔργων τῶν ἐν δικαιοσύνῃ, ἃ ἐποιήσαμεν ἡμεῖς
Question: What was it that Paul says did not save us?
What was it that Paul says did save us?
What image did Paul use for the **washing** through which God saved us?
Who was it that renewed us in order to save us?
Who was it that gave the Holy Spirit to us?
What does the image of the Holy Spirit being **richly poured on us** tell you about your relationship to the Holy Spirit?

Quote: οὗ ἐξέχεεν ἐφ’ ἡμᾶς πλουσίως, διὰ Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ, τοῦ Σωτῆρος ἡμῶν
Question: In verses 5-6, Paul states that the Holy Spirit, God, and Jesus were all active in saving us. Why is it important that he listed all three?
How does the title Paul here uses for Jesus compare to verse 4? Why is that important?
What does it mean to be **justified** by God? Why is that important?
What is it that caused God to justify us?
What does it mean to become an heir? To whom have we become heirs?
What **certain hope** do we have because God saved us?
**This message** may refer back to verses 4-7, or to the entire book. What does it mean when Paul says it is **trustworthy**? Why should that be important to you?
Paul said in verse 5 that **works of righteousness** do not cause our salvation, but he says in 2:6, 2:14, and 3:8 that we should do them. For what other reason are they important?

Quote: μωρὰς & ζητήσεις, καὶ γενεαλογίας, καὶ ἔρεις, καὶ μάχας νομικὰς
Question: What are some examples of foolish things people talk about, or things that cause strife between people?
What does Paul say is the value of these debates and conflicts?
What is an example of a **divisive person**?
Why should we warn a divisive person once or twice instead of rejecting him immediately?
Why does Paul describe being divisive as turning **from the right way**?
Why would Paul say that a divisive person is **self-condemned**?

Quote: σπούδασον ἐλθεῖν πρός με εἰς Νικόπολιν
Question: What did Paul want Titus to do when Artemas or Tychicus arrive in Crete?

Quote: σπουδαίως πρόπεμψον, ἵνα μηδὲν αὐτοῖς λείπῃ
Question: What exactly did Paul want Titus and the believers in Crete to do for Zenas and Apollos **so that they lack nothing**?

Quote: καλῶν ἔργων προΐστασθαι εἰς τὰς ἀναγκαίας χρείας
Question: What did Paul want the believers in Crete to learn to do?
What are some examples of **essential needs**?
What image did Paul use to describe a believer who does not do good works?

Quote: ἀσπάζονταί σε οἱ μετ’ ἐμοῦ πάντες. ἄσπασαι τοὺς φιλοῦντας ἡμᾶς ἐν πίστει
Question: Paul always passed greetings between the believers and churches. Why is that so important to do?
What does it mean to **love** another believer **in faith**?
As Paul’s closing desire in this letter, what did he want all the believers in Crete to receive?
